Question: How many fundamental units in physics?
The fundamental units used in aerodynamics are?
Option A: Mass, length and Velocity.
Option B: Mass, length, time, pressure and temperature.
Option C: Mass, length, time and temperature.
Correct Answer: Mass, length, time, pressure and temperature.

Question: What is sea level pressure?
Acceleration is?
Option A: The change in speed divided by the time during which the change takes place.
Option B: The distance that a moving object covers in a unit of time.
Option C: Denoted by v, which comes from the Latin word velocitas.
Correct Answer: The change in speed divided by the time during which the change takes place.

Question: A standard atmosphere was introduced by?
Option A: ICAO
Option B: CAAV
Option C: Vietnam Airlines
Correct Answer: ICAO

Question: Static pressure acts?
Option A: Only in the direction of the flow
Option B: Equally in all directions
Option C: Only in the direction of aircraft motion.
Correct Answer: Equally in all directions

Question: The speed of sound is less at high altitudes because the temperature?
Option A: Is constant.
Option B: Is higher.
Option C: Is lower.
Correct Answer: Is lower.

Question: Temperature at altitude above 11km will?
Option A: Increase exponentially.
Option B: Decrease exponentially.
Option C: Remain constant.
Correct Answer: Remain constant.

Question: With increasing altitude at altitude from 3 to 8 km, pressure decreases and?
Option A: Temperature increases.
Option B: Temperature decreases.
Option C: Temperature remains constant.
Correct Answer: Temperature decreases.

Question: How do you understand about the tropopause?
Option A: The tropopause has different heights around the earth.
Option B: The tropopause has the heights less than 3 kilometers over the equator.
Option C: The tropopause has the same heights around the earth.
Correct Answer: The tropopause has different heights around the earth.

Question: The continuity equation states that the speed of the airflow is?
Option A: Inversely proportional to the area of the cross section of the tube as long as the density remains constant.
Option B: Proportional to the area of the cross section of the tube as long as the density remains constant.
Option C: Inversely proportional to the area of the cross section of the tube as long as the density changes.
Correct Answer: Inversely proportional to the area of the cross section of the tube as long as the density remains constant.

Question: The coefficient of lift is the measured lift divided by?
Option A: Theoretical drag.
Option B: Theoretical lift.
Option C: Theoretical push.
Correct Answer: Theoretical lift.

Question: In the subsonic region, the speed is?
Option A: Constant.
Option B: So slow that a flying body does not compress the air.
Option C: So high that a flying body does not compress the air.
Correct Answer: So slow that a flying body does not compress the air.

Question: Which of the following is true?
Option A: Lift acts at right angles to the relative airflow and weight acts vertically down.
Option B: Lift acts at right angles to the wing chord line and weight acts vertically down.
Option C: Lift acts at right angles to the relative air flow and weight acts at right angles to the aircraft centre line.
Correct Answer: Lift acts at right angles to the relative airflow and weight acts vertically down.

Question: A profile is?
Option A: A cross section of a wing.
Option B: A cross section of a fuselage.
Option C: A cross section of a Tailcone.
Correct Answer: A cross section of a wing.

Question: The chord line of a wing is a line that runs from?
Option A: The centre of the leading edge of the wing to the trailing edge.
Option B: Half way between the upper and lower surface of the wing.
Option C: One wing tip to the other wing tip.
Correct Answer: The centre of the leading edge of the wing to the trailing edge.

Question: How many different wing shapes with their lift distribution?
What is the definition of Angle of Incidence?
Option A: The angle the underside of the mainplane or tailplane makes with the horizontal.
Option B: The angle the underside of the mainplane or tailplane makes with the longitudinal datum line.
Option C: The angle between the chord line of the profile and the longitudinal axis of the aircraft.
Correct Answer: The angle between the chord line of the profile and the longitudinal axis of the aircraft.

Question: The angle of attack is?
Option A: The angle between the chord line of the profile and the longitudinal axis of the aircraft.
Option B: The angle the underside of the mainplane or tailplane makes with the horizontal.
Option C: The angle between the chord line of the profile and the relative wind.
Correct Answer: The angle between the chord line of the profile and the relative wind.

Question: The aspect ratio is?
Option A: The wing span, b, divided by the average chord, c.
Option B: The wing span, b, divided by the lift.
Option C: The wing span, b, divided by the drag.
Correct Answer: The wing span, b, divided by the average chord, c.

Question: For a given aerofoil production lift, where P = pressure and V = velocity.
Option A: P1 is greater than P2, and V1 is less than V2.
Option B: P1 is greater than P2, and V1 is greater than V2.
Option C: P1 is less than P2 and V1 is greater than V2.
Correct Answer: P1 is greater than P2, and V1 is less than V2.

Question: The aerodynamic force has?
Option A: Two components
Option B: Three components
Option C: Four components
Correct Answer: Two components

Question: A Lift is?
Option A: Perpendicular to the chord line.
Option B: Perpendicular to aircraft axis.
Option C: Perpendicular to the relative wind.
Correct Answer: Perpendicular to the relative wind.

Question: The maximum camber and the location or the maximum camber help to?
Option A: Define the lift.
Option B: Define the drag.
Option C: Define the shape of the mean camber line.
Correct Answer: Define the shape of the mean camber line.

Question: The relative wind depends on?
Option A: The flight path and is therefore not always horizontal.
Option B: The angle of attack and is therefore not always horizontal.
Option C: The angle of attack and is always horizontal.
Correct Answer: The flight path and is therefore not always horizontal.

Question: When the cylinder rotates the circulatory flow causes?
Option A: An decrease in local speed on the upper surface of the cylinder and a decrease in local speed on the lower surface.
Option B: An increase in local speed on the upper surface of the cylinder and a decrease in local speed on the lower surface.
Option C: An increase in local speed on the lower surface of the cylinder and a decrease in local speed on the lower surface.
Correct Answer: An increase in local speed on the upper surface of the cylinder and a decrease in local speed on the lower surface.

Question: The turbulent boundary layer also produces?
Option A: Lower kinetic energy next to the surface and this reduces the tendency for a flow separation.
Option B: Higher kinetic energy next to the surface and this reduces the tendency for a flow separation.
Option C: Higher kinetic energy next to the surface and this increase the tendency for a flow separation.
Correct Answer: Higher kinetic energy next to the surface and this reduces the tendency for a flow separation.

Question: When we have a flow separation at the root of the wing, the center of lift?
Option A: Moves towards the root and also behind the center of gravity.
Option B: Moves towards the tip and also behind the center of gravity.
Option C: Moves towards the tip and also before the center of gravity.
Correct Answer: Moves towards the tip and also behind the center of gravity.

Question: When does the angle of incidence change?
Option A: It never changes.
Option B: When the aircraft attitude changes.
Option C: When the aircraft is ascending or descending.
Correct Answer: It never changes.

Question: If the wing span is infinite the circulation around the profile causes?
Option A: An downwash on the leading edge and a downwash on the trailing edge.
Option B: An upwash on the leading edge and an upwash on the trailing edge.
Option C: An upwash on the leading edge and a downwash on the trailing edge.
Correct Answer: An upwash on the leading edge and a downwash on the trailing edge.

Question: Upper surface frost and especially leading edge ice formation reduce?
Option A: The maximum coefficient of drag and the maximum angle of attack.
Option B: The maximum coefficient of lift and the maximum angle of incidence.
Option C: The maximum coefficient of lift and the maximum angle of attack.
Correct Answer: The maximum coefficient of lift and the maximum angle of attack.

Question: A flow separation at the tip of the wing is much more dangerous. It causes?
Option A: The center of lift moves towards the root and also forward of the center of gravity.
Option B: The center of lift moves towards the tip and also forward of the center of gravity.
Option C: The center of lift moves towards the root and also aft of the center of gravity.
Correct Answer: The center of lift moves towards the root and also forward of the center of gravity.

Question: Different wing shapes are?
Option A: An elliptical wing, a rectangular wing, a tapered wing, a swept wing
Option B: An elliptical wing, a rectangular wing.
Option C: An elliptical wing, a swept wing
Correct Answer: An elliptical wing, a rectangular wing, a tapered wing, a swept wing

Question: On an aerodynamically twisted wing the camber of the profile at the root is?
Option A: Smaller than the camber at the tip and the angle of incidence is constant across the wing span.
Option B: Greater than the camber at the tip and the angle of incidence is increased across the wing span.
Option C: Greater than the camber at the tip and the angle of incidence is constant across the wing span.
Correct Answer: Greater than the camber at the tip and the angle of incidence is constant across the wing span.

Question: On a geometrically twisted wing the camber of the profile is?
Option A: Smaller than the camber at the tip and the angle of incidence is constant across the wing span.
Option B: Greater than the camber at the tip and the angle of incidence is increased across the wing span.
Option C: Constant across the span of the wing but the angle of incidence is greater at the root than at the tip.
Correct Answer: Constant across the span of the wing but the angle of incidence is greater at the root than at the tip.

Question: When the position of the center of lift moves forward of the position of the center of gravity we have?
Option A: A nose up reaction.
Option B: A down up reaction.
Option C: No nose up or down reaction.
Correct Answer: A nose up reaction.

Question: What is Thrust?
Option A: The force which moves the aircraft forward through the air.
Option B: Provided by jet engines or by a propeller.
Option C: The aerodynamic force which is parallel to the flight path.
Correct Answer: The force which moves the aircraft forward through the air.

Question: What is Drag?
Option A: The aerodynamic force which is parallel to the flight path.
Option B: The force which moves the aircraft forward through the air.
Option C: Provided by jet engines or by a propeller.
Correct Answer: The aerodynamic force which is parallel to the flight path.

Question: What is Lift?
Option A: The aerodynamic force which is ninety degrees to the flight path.
Option B: The force which moves the aircraft forward through the air.
Option C: Provided by jet engines or by a propeller.
Correct Answer: The aerodynamic force which is ninety degrees to the flight path.

Question: If an aircraft moves in yaw, what axis does it move about?
Option A: Longitudinal.
Option B: Lateral.
Option C: Vertical.
Correct Answer: Vertical.

Question: What does Lateral stability refer to?
Option A: The roll movement around the longitudinal axis.
Option B: The yaw movement around the vertical axis.
Option C: The pitch movement around the lateral axis.
Correct Answer: The roll movement around the longitudinal axis.

Question: What does Directional stability refer to?
Option A: The yaw movement around the vertical axis.
Option B: The pitch movement around the lateral axis.
Option C: The roll movement around the longitudinal axis.
Correct Answer: The yaw movement around the vertical axis.

Question: What does Longitudinal stability refer to?
Option A: The pitch movement around the lateral axis.
Option B: The roll movement around the longitudinal axis.
Option C: The yaw movement around the vertical axis.
Correct Answer: The pitch movement around the lateral axis.

Question: What is Weight?
Option A: The force of thrust.
Option B: The force of pressure.
Option C: The force of gravity.
Correct Answer: The force of gravity.

Question: How many degrees to the flight path of Lift force?
Option A: 90 degrees
Option B: 70 degrees
Option C: 50 degrees
Correct Answer: 90 degrees

Question: What can The center of gravity be thought of as?
Option A: A center of pressure.
Option B: A center of balance.
Option C: A center of lift.
Correct Answer: A center of balance.

Question: When does an equilibrium exist?
Option A: The aircraft is in descent flight.
Option B: The aircraft is in climb flight.
Option C: The aircraft is in steady, level flight.
Correct Answer: The aircraft is in steady, level flight.

Question: What does The lift on the wing has to carry?
Option A: The weight of the aircraft only
Option B: The downward acting stabilizer force only
Option C: The weight of the aircraft and the downward acting stabilizer force.
Correct Answer: The weight of the aircraft and the downward acting stabilizer force.

Question: When Moments = Zero?
Option A: Anti-clockwise Rotation > Clockwise Rotation
Option B: Anti-clockwise Rotation< Clockwise Rotation
Option C: Anti-clockwise Rotation = Clockwise Rotation
Correct Answer: Anti-clockwise Rotation = Clockwise Rotation

Question: If the aircraft is to maintain altitude during a turn, the lift in the turn?
Option A: Must not be equal to the resultant of the centrifugal force and the weight.
Option B: Must be equal to the resultant of the centrifugal force and the weight.
Option C: Must be equal to the resultant of the centrifugal force or the weight.
Correct Answer: Must be equal to the resultant of the centrifugal force and the weight.

Question: The load factor ”n” is also called?
Option A: G−load
Option B: W-load
Option C: V−load
Correct Answer: G−load

Question: When an aircraft is in constant altitude, wings level flight, the lift is?
Option A: Equal to the weight of the aircraft.
Option B: Smaller to the weight of the aircraft.
Option C: Bigger to the weight of the aircraft.
Correct Answer: Equal to the weight of the aircraft.

Question: The structural strength of the aircraft and consideration for passenger comfort limit?
Option A: The maximum angle of attack during a turn.
Option B: The maximum load factor.
Option C: The maximum speed during a turn.
Correct Answer: The maximum load factor.

Question: The load factor on military is much?
Option A: Higher than on passenger aircraft.
Option B: Lower than on passenger aircraft.
Option C: Higher than on acrobatic aircraft.
Correct Answer: Higher than on passenger aircraft.

Question: What happens when the aircraft is in cruise flight?
Option A: The coefficient of lift is much less than the maximum coefficient of lift.
Option B: The coefficient of lift is equal the maximum coefficient of lift.
Option C: The coefficient of lift is minimum.
Correct Answer: The coefficient of lift is much less than the maximum coefficient of lift.

Question: When the aircraft is in low speed flight?
Option A: The coefficient of lift is at, or close to, the maximum.
Option B: The coefficient of lift above the maximum.
Option C: The coefficient of lift is higher the maximum.
Correct Answer: The coefficient of lift is at, or close to, the maximum.

Question: Directional stability is about?
Option A: The lateral axis.
Option B: The longitudinal axis.
Option C: The vertical axis.
Correct Answer: The vertical axis.

Question: Lateral stability is about?
Option A: The longitudinal axis.
Option B: The normal axis.
Option C: The vertical axis.
Correct Answer: The longitudinal axis.

Question: The Aircraft Fin gives stability about which axis?
Option A: Longitudinal axis.
Option B: Lateral axis.
Option C: Vertical axis.
Correct Answer: Vertical axis.

Question: How many type of stability?
In static stability, when the ball is displaced from the center on a concave surface?
Option A: It returns to its original position of equilibrium.
Option B: It moves away from its original position of equilibrium.
Option C: It shows no tendency to roll back or away from its original position of equilibrium.
Correct Answer: It returns to its original position of equilibrium.

Question: What is Dutch roll?
Option A: Longitudinal − directional oscillation.
Option B: Vertical − directional oscillation.
Option C: Lateral − directional oscillation.
Correct Answer: Lateral − directional oscillation.

Question: What is the sideslip angle?
Option A: The angle between the aircraft centerline and the sideslip direction.
Option B: The angle between the aircraft centerline and the wing axis.
Option C: The angle between the aircraft centerline and the fuselage axis.
Correct Answer: The angle between the aircraft centerline and the sideslip direction.

Question: What is Longitudinal stability?
Option A: Longitudinal stability is the stability of the aircraft around the vertical axis.
Option B: Longitudinal stability is the stability of the aircraft around the lateral axis.
Option C: Longitudinal stability is the stability of the aircraft around the longitudinal axis.
Correct Answer: Longitudinal stability is the stability of the aircraft around the lateral axis.

Question: The gust moves the right wing upward and the left wing downward and the aircraft rotates around?
Option A: The lateral axis.
Option B: The longitudinal axis.
Option C: The vertical axis.
Correct Answer: The longitudinal axis.

Question: The nose up rotation also produces additional lift on the wing because of?
Option A: The decreasing angle of incidence.
Option B: The decreasing angle of attack.
Option C: The increasing angle of attack.
Correct Answer: The increasing angle of attack.

Question: When a gust hits the upper front part of the aircraft, what do we get?
Option A: We get a nose up rotation.
Option B: We get a nose down rotation.
Option C: We get no rotation of nose.
Correct Answer: We get a nose down rotation.

Question: What does The longitudinal stability depend on?
Option A: The angle of incidence and the pitching moment effects of the horizontal stabilizer and the wing.
Option B: The angle of attack and the pitching moment effects of the horizontal stabilizer and the wing.
Option C: The angle of attack and the pitching moment effects of the vertical stabilizer and the wing.
Correct Answer: The angle of attack and the pitching moment effects of the horizontal stabilizer and the wing.

Question: When do dynamic stability apply?
Option A: Dynamic stability only applies if we have neutral static stability.
Option B: Dynamic stability only applies if we have positive static stability.
Option C: Dynamic stability only applies if we have negative static stability.
Correct Answer: Dynamic stability only applies if we have positive static stability.

Question: The dutch roll problem is found on all aircraft with?
Option A: Tapered wings.
Option B: Rectangular.
Option C: Swept wings. ----HẾT---
Correct Answer: Swept wings. ----HẾT---
